Requirements: To apply for the Master of Public Administration program, applicants must complete the Graduate Application for Admission, submit a 2-3 page statement of purpose responding to a specific prompt, submit a current résumé detailing educational and work experience, provide two letters of recommendation submitted through the online application system, submit official transcripts from all previously attended colleges, and submit a 3-4 page Critical Essay on an Issue in Public Administration based on a provided topic. A $50 application fee is also required. Some applicants may be invited for an interview.
Concentration: Public & Nonprofit Administration, Public Policy, Tribal Governance
Description: Our Master of Public Administration (MPA) program offers an interdisciplinary curriculum that responds to the changing needs of the public and nonprofit sectors. You’ll be prepared for leadership and management positions in public service, from small local nonprofits to large federal agencies. You’ll learn to engage in thoughtful inquiry and act in the public interest with compassion, competence, and commitment. You’ll learn: Critical thinking, writing, quantitative and qualitative analysis to support decision making and problem solving. Collaborative leadership in diverse organizations and communities. How to define public problems and opportunities, analyze policies, and manage programs with an equity lens. Ethical public service that is responsible, accountable, and dedicated to pursuing the public interest.

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to take an English language proficiency test. You can provide scores for TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo. We look for a minimum score of 80 on TOEFL IBT, 6.0 on IELTS, or 105 on the Duolingo English Test. If your secondary or postsecondary education was completed in English, you may be able to waive the English proficiency requirement.
Requirements: To be considered for admission, you will need to submit a complete application. Your application will consist of: Online application with non-refundable fee ($50). Statement of Purpose. Resume. Unofficial transcripts from all colleges/universities you attended. Official transcripts will be required upon acceptance. Two letters of recommendation. Writing Sample (optional).
Description: The Master of Environmental Studies (MES) is a two-year, interdisciplinary graduate degree that prepares you to work in a wide variety of environmental fields. You’ll learn to combine science, policy, and community action to understand and solve complex environmental problems. Our graduates are respected for their skills, confidence, and professionalism. The MES program started in 1984 and has an alumni network of over 1,000 working in environmental professions around the world. We offer a distinctive approach to graduate education based on our interdisciplinary curriculum, collaborative and interactive learning environment, and narrative evaluations instead of grades. You’ll become part of a close-knit and supportive community of learners as you explore the environmental challenges of the Pacific Northwest and the world.

Requirements: A complete application for the Master in Teaching program includes: an online Application for Graduate Study, a two-page Statement of Purpose, official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, three letters of recommendation submitted through the online application system, passing scores for the Washington Educator Skills Test-Basic (WEST-B) or an approved alternative, documentation meeting the endorsement requirement, a Character & Fitness Supplement, and an interview. An application fee is also required.
Concentration: K-8 Elementary Education, K-12 Special Education, K-12 Reading, English Language Learner
Description: The Master in Teaching (MiT) Program at The Evergreen State College prepares and supports justice-oriented teachers for public schools. We support our teacher candidates in developing the knowledge, skills, and dispositions to bring Evergreen’s five foci to their own work in K-12 classrooms: collaborative, interdisciplinary, student-centered, hands-on, and community-based learning. We are a full-time, in-person, four-quarter cohort program that culminates in a Master in Teaching degree and a Washington State teaching certificate with endorsements in K-8 Elementary Education and/or K-12 Special Education. We also offer pathways to a K-12 Reading endorsement and an English Language Learner endorsement. While in our program, candidates are placed in a professional-track internship in a K-12 public school classroom throughout the school year. They have the opportunity to work alongside an experienced mentor teacher and to connect theory from their graduate coursework to the practice of teaching.
Accredidation: The Master in Teaching (MiT) program is approved by the Professional Educator Standards Board (PESB).

EnglishScore: Evergreen does not require you to take an English language proficiency exam (TOEFL or IELTS) to be admitted. However, we may recommend that you consider enrolling in a program at an ESL school before attending Evergreen.
Description:
The Evergreen State College is excited to offer a new Master of Business Administration (MBA) in Sustainability. With classes set to begin in Fall 2022, students can expect to gain the necessary business skills and knowledge to lead and manage organizations in an ever-changing world with complex economic, social and environmental challenges.

The program will focus on strategic thinking, leadership, and collaboration through applied learning taught by a team of faculty who have business and organizational leadership experience. The program provides the business credentials students need to succeed in their careers while also making a positive impact on their communities and the world.

Evergreen’s MBA program will allow students to graduate with the knowledge to manage finances and understand markets, build collaborative organizations, and have the skills to implement long-term goals for success in a sustainable and equitable manner.
Accredidation: The MBA program is currently undergoing accreditation review. More information will be available soon.

ProgramName: Master of Public Administration in Tribal Governance
EnglishScore:
You can demonstrate proficiency by submitting one of the following:

Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) with a minimum score of 80 on the iBT.
International English Language Testing System (IELTS) with a minimum score of 6.5.
Duolingo English Test with a minimum score of 105.
Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic with a minimum score of 59.
Successful completion of the ELS Language Centers’ Level 112.
Requirements:
All applicants must submit:

An online application for admission to The Evergreen State College Graduate School for the MPA program.
An application fee of $50 (this fee may be waived based on financial need).
Official transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities.
At least two letters of recommendation from faculty who have taught you, or supervisors who know your work.
Statement of purpose describing how the MPA program will help you meet your personal and professional goals (500–750 words).
A resume listing your relevant work and volunteer experience.
An analytical essay based on one of two prompts (500–750 words).
Description: The Tribal Governance concentration is the first of its kind in the nation. It is designed for students who are or intend to be managers or leaders in tribal governments or in organizations that work with tribal governments. The concentration addresses the history and legal status of American Indian tribes and the unique governance issues they face. The curriculum emphasizes tribal sovereignty, ethics, and values.
Accredidation: Evergreen's MPA program is accredited by the Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration (NASPAA) Commission on Peer Review and Accreditation and listed on the annual roster of accredited programs in conformity with NASPAA standards.

ProgramName: Master of Public Administration in Public Policy
EnglishScore: International students can prove proficiency in English with one of the following: TOEFL score of 72 iBT / 530 PBT, IELTS score of 6.0, Duolingo English Test score of 105, PTE Academic score of 52, or successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112. The requirement may be waived for students with official transcripts from a high school, college or university in the United States, United Kingdom, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, or English-speaking provinces of Canada.
Requirements:
All applicants to the MPA program must submit the following materials to be considered for admission:

*   Graduate Application
*   Application Fee
*   Statement of Purpose: In 500-1000 words, tell us why you are applying to Evergreen’s MPA program. This is your opportunity to demonstrate your writing ability and to tell us about your personal and professional goals.
*   Résumé: Upload a current résumé that highlights your professional and/or academic experience and skills relevant to the MPA program. For applicants with limited professional experience, highlight your relevant volunteer and community service.
*   Official College Transcripts: Official transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities are required.
*   Letters of Recommendation: Three letters of recommendation are required from academic or professional references who can attest to your ability to do graduate-level work.
*   Analytical Writing Prerequisite: Applicants must be able to demonstrate they have met the prerequisite by submitting one of the following:
    *   An official transcript showing successful completion of an analytical writing-intensive course or courses in the social sciences, humanities, or sciences. The course(s) must have been completed within the past 5 years and with a grade of 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale).
    *   A scored analytical writing section of the GRE from a test taken within the past 5 years. A score of 4.5 or higher is required.
    *   A 3-5 page analytical essay.
    *   Completion of the MPA Program’s Public Policy and Governance (PP&G) course, taken through open enrollment within the past 5 years. A grade of 3.0 or higher is required.
    *   For applicants with a graduate degree from a regionally-accredited college or university in the U.S. (or its equivalent in another country) may submit their Academic Statement of Purpose in lieu of the Analytical Writing Prerequisite.
Description: Prepare for a career as a policy analyst or for policy advocacy. You'll gain a firm foundation in the policy process, including analysis, research, strategies, and implementation. Electives can be tailored to fit your policy area of interest.
Accredidation: Evergreen's MPA program is accredited by the Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration (NASPAA).

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to demonstrate English proficiency. You can submit one of the following: TOEFL minimum score of 72 iBT or 525 PBT; IELTS minimum score of 6.0; Duolingo English Test minimum score of 105; Pearson Test of English (PTE) minimum score of 53; Completion of ELS Language Centers level 112.
Requirements: To apply as a first-year student, you’ll need to submit: Your application, an application essay, and official transcripts. Submitting SAT and ACT scores is optional.

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to submit proof of English proficiency. You can meet this requirement in any of the following ways: TOEFL: 79 iBT / 550 PBT, IELTS: 6.0, Duolingo English Test: 105, Pearson Test of English (PTE): 53, ELS Language Centers: Level 112. This requirement can also be met by successful completion of 2 years in a U.S. high school or 1 year in a U.S. college, including a college-level English composition course with a grade of 3.0 (B) or higher; successful completion of a U.S. associate’s degree; or graduation from a high school in which the primary language of instruction was English.
Requirements: To apply as a first-year student, you'll need to submit the Evergreen application or the Common App, a $50 nonrefundable fee or fee waiver, a required essay, and an official transcript from the last high school you attended. Evergreen is test-optional.

EnglishScore: If English is not your first language, you will need to submit proof of your English proficiency. You can meet this requirement in any one of the following ways: TOEFL: Minimum score of 72 on the internet-based test (iBT) or 525 on the paper-based test (PBT). IELTS: Overall band score of 6.0. Duolingo English Test (DET): Minimum score of 100. ELS Language Centers: Completion of level 112 of the ELS English for Academic Purposes program. Pearson Test of English (PTE): Minimum score of 52.
Requirements:
To apply for first-year admission, you'll need to submit:

Application: You can apply using the Evergreen Application or the Common Application.
Application Fee: A nonrefundable $50 application fee. You can request a fee waiver if you can't afford the fee.
Transcripts: Official high school transcript or official GED scores.
Essay: An essay on one of two prompts is required.
Test Scores (Optional): We are test-optional. If you choose to submit them, send us your official ACT or SAT scores.

ProgramName: Interdisciplinary Arts and Sciences at Olympia
EnglishScore: If English is not your first language, you will need to provide proof of English language proficiency.
Requirements: To apply for first-year admission, you will need to submit: Application for Admission, a nonrefundable $50 application fee, and official high school transcripts or GED results.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $11,250 depending on the scholarship

EnglishScore: Proof of English language proficiency is required if your native language is not English. Accepted options include: TOEFL (minimum 72 iBT or 525 PBT), IELTS (minimum 6.0), Duolingo English Test (minimum 95), ELS Language Centers (completion of level 112), or Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic (minimum 53). The requirement may also be met by completing Freshman Composition at a U.S. institution or graduating from a high school in an English-speaking country.
Requirements: Applicants must submit the Application for Admission, a nonrefundable application fee, official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended (or high school transcript for first-year applicants), and an essay. The essay is a critical part of the application, providing an opportunity to tell the admissions committee more about yourself.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $500 to full in-state tuition
ScholarshipType: Academic achievement, Financial need, Field of study, Community service, Leadership

Requirements: To be considered for the Native Pathways Program, applicants must first apply and be admitted to The Evergreen State College as a first-year, transfer, or post-baccalaureate student. All applicants who are admitted to Evergreen and who are an enrolled member or descendant of an American Indian/Alaska Native/First Nations tribe are automatically considered for the Native Pathways Program. General application requirements for first-year students include an Application for Admission, an essay (200-500 words), an official High School Transcript or GED Certificate, and a $50 Application Fee.
Description: The Native Pathways Program (NPP) is an upper-division transfer program designed for Indigenous students pursuing a bachelor's degree at The Evergreen State College. This unique academic program helps Indigenous students transfer their associate's degree to Evergreen, offering tailored support and community as they complete their bachelor's. Our Indigenous faculty and staff provide holistic advising to help students navigate their academic journey, identify career goals, and build community. We offer rigorous academic coursework focused on Indigenous topics and perspectives, which fulfills Evergreen's bachelor's degree requirements. NPP faculty are interdisciplinary and collaborate with students in developing individualized academic plans and pathways. NPP offers an academic path to a bachelor’s degree from Evergreen. This path can lead to a variety of degree programs, including but not limited to Native American and Indigenous Studies (NAIS), Tribal Governance, Political Science, Environmental Studies, Public Administration, and Education.

ProgramName: Applied Computer Science and Information Technology
EnglishScore: If English is not your first language, you will need to submit proof of English proficiency. You can show proficiency with one of the following: TOEFL: minimum score of 72 iBT / 530 PBT. IELTS: minimum score of 6.0. Duolingo English Test: minimum score of 100. ELS Language Centers: successful completion of level 112.
Requirements: All first-year applicants must submit a completed application for admission, official high school transcript or official copy of GED test results, and an essay. One letter of recommendation is recommended, but not required. SAT or ACT scores are optional and not required for admission.
CostPerCredit: $315 for first 2 credits, $226 for each additional credit (Resident)

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to submit one of the following to demonstrate your English proficiency: TOEFL: minimum 76 iBT, IELTS: minimum 6.0 overall band score, Duolingo English Test (DET): minimum 100, Successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112.
Requirements: To apply as a first-year student, you’ll need to submit: The Evergreen Application or the Common App. Your essay. Official transcripts from all high schools and colleges you’ve attended. The nonrefundable $50 application fee. We also welcome optional materials like test scores, letters of recommendation, and a resume or portfolio.
Description: El Camino is a program for students interested in Latinx Studies, Latin American Studies, and/or Multilingual Studies. It brings together multiple disciplines and ways of knowing to understand the history, politics, arts, literatures, social movements, and cultures of Latinx people in the U.S. and Latin America, as well as the sociolinguistics of multilingualism, second language acquisition, and Spanish language pedagogy. El Camino is designed for undergraduates with an intermediate or advanced level of Spanish, and it offers an opportunity to deepen their engagement with social sciences, humanities, and arts through the lens of language and culture. Students can expect to improve their Spanish language proficiency and intercultural communication skills, as well as develop critical analysis skills by studying the theories, histories, and cultural production of Latinx and Latin American peoples.

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to submit proof of English proficiency. You can meet this requirement with a TOEFL minimum score of 72 iBT, IELTS minimum score of 6.0, Duolingo English Test minimum score of 100, Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic minimum score of 53, or completion of ELS Language Centers level 112.
Requirements: To be considered for admission, you must submit a completed application including: Application (either the Evergreen Application or the Common Application), Nonrefundable $50 application fee or waiver, Personal Essay, Official high school transcript or GED certificate.

EnglishScore: If English is not your first language, you will need to provide proof of English proficiency. This can be met through various options including TOEFL (minimum score of 72 iBT), IELTS (minimum score of 6.0), Duolingo English Test (minimum score of 100), PTE Academic (minimum score of 53), or completion of ELS Language Centers level 112.
Requirements: To apply for first-year admission, you need to submit: Application: Submit the Evergreen application or the Common App. Essay: We require an essay on a topic of your choice. This is your chance to show us what you care about and how you think. High school transcript(s). Application fee of $50.
Description:
Literature is a fundamental way that humans imagine and represent themselves and their worlds. At Evergreen, you’ll study the literature of different places, periods, and genres. Through reading, discussion, and writing, you’ll investigate the historical and cultural contexts of literary works while honing your own analytical skills. You’ll learn how literature both reflects and shapes societies and how it impacts individuals. Evergreen’s interdisciplinary approach means that you’ll have opportunities to connect your literary studies with other fields, such as history, philosophy, gender studies, media studies, political economy, and fine arts.

Some of the questions you might explore include: How do literary forms and conventions develop? How do stories travel and change across cultures and time? How do authors use language and imagery to create meaning? How do literary works engage with social issues such as race, class, gender, and environmental justice? What roles do writers and literature play in society?
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $100 up to the full cost of attendance

ProgramName: El Camino: Latinx Studies, Latin American Studies, and Multilingual Education
EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to submit proof of English language proficiency. Options include a minimum TOEFL score of 72 iBT, IELTS minimum score of 6.0, Duolingo English Test minimum score of 100, PTE Academic minimum score of 53, or completion of ELS Language Centers level 112.
Requirements: To apply for admission as a first-year student, you will need to submit: The Evergreen application or the Common Application; A $50 nonrefundable application fee or fee waiver; Official high school and/or college transcripts; One essay.
Description:
El Camino: Latinx Studies, Latin American Studies, and Multilingual Education is a full-time, interdisciplinary program offered collaboratively through the Latinx Studies, Latin American Studies, and World Languages and Cultures academic programs. El Camino offers a unique learning experience at Evergreen by blending history, cultural studies, social sciences, and literary studies with a strong emphasis on Spanish language acquisition and multilingual education. The program focuses on the experiences and cultures of Latinx people in the United States, Latin American countries, and the broader Spanish-speaking world.

Students in El Camino will engage with critical issues related to identity, migration, social justice, and cultural expression within Latinx and Latin American contexts. The curriculum is designed to foster critical thinking, cultural competency, and language proficiency through a variety of instructional methods including seminars, workshops, cultural events, and community-engaged learning. Students will develop skills in research, analysis, and communication relevant to diverse career paths in education, social services, advocacy, arts, and international relations.

A key component of El Camino is its focus on multilingual education, preparing students to engage with diverse linguistic communities and to understand the role of language in identity formation and social power. Students will have opportunities to enhance their Spanish language skills through coursework ranging from intermediate to advanced levels, and to explore theories and practices of language teaching and learning. The program also encourages students to think about how their learning can be applied to real-world issues, including service learning and internships with organizations working with Latinx communities.

El Camino is an excellent choice for students interested in pursuing careers in education (especially bilingual education), social work, community organizing, public policy, translation, international development, and cultural resource management. It also provides a strong foundation for graduate studies in Latinx Studies, Latin American Studies, education, linguistics, and related fields.

EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to submit proof of English proficiency. You can submit one of the following to meet this requirement: TOEFL (Test of English as a Foreign Language) with a minimum score of 550 on the paper-based test (PBT) or 79 on the internet-based test (iBT), IELTS (International English Language Testing System) with a minimum score of 6.5, Duolingo English Test with a minimum score of 105, PTE Academic (Pearson Test of English) with a minimum score of 53, or ELS Language Centers completion of level 112.
Requirements: A complete application includes: Application for Admission, $50 Application Fee, Official High School Transcript or GED certificate.
Description: Environmental Solutions is a science program for students ready to address the greatest environmental challenges facing humanity and the planet. This problem-based, interdisciplinary curriculum prepares students for graduate school or careers focused on creating and implementing solutions to complex environmental issues. The Environmental Solutions program at Evergreen offers an applied, hands-on learning experience grounded in scientific knowledge and a transdisciplinary approach to problem-solving. Through field and lab work, you will develop the skills to design and implement innovative and effective solutions to complex environmental problems. You’ll learn to think critically, communicate effectively, collaborate productively, and approach challenges creatively as you prepare for a career in environmental problem-solving. As part of this program, you will also build a network of faculty and fellow students who are passionate about creating a better world.

EnglishScore: Proof of English proficiency is required for applicants whose native language is not English. Accepted tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT 79, IELTS 6.5, Duolingo 105, or successful completion of ELS Language Centers level 112. Waivers are available under certain conditions.
Requirements: To apply for admission as a first-year student, you’ll need: a completed admission application, a nonrefundable $50 application fee or fee waiver, official high school transcripts (or GED test results), and one essay from the list of prompts. Test scores (SAT or ACT) are optional.
Description: Environmental Studies at Evergreen allows you to focus on many aspects of this vast field, from ecology and natural sciences to public policy and environmental justice, to sustainable agriculture and ecological design. Our interdisciplinary approach means you’ll study the environment from different perspectives, including science, social science, humanities, and arts. You’ll gain skills and experience in areas such as field science, policy analysis, community organizing, GIS, and environmental education. You’ll learn how to approach environmental issues from multiple angles and work collaboratively to address complex challenges. Explore your interests in areas like ecological restoration, environmental communication, marine science, sustainable agriculture, and environmental policy, preparing you for a wide range of careers.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose first language is not English must submit evidence of English proficiency. Accepted methods include TOEFL iBT with a minimum score of 72, IELTS with a minimum score of 6.0, Duolingo English Test (DET) with a minimum score of 100, Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic with a minimum score of 53, or completion of ELS Language Centers level 112.
Description: This program examines environmental justice from multiple perspectives. We will explore the historical roots of environmental injustice, analyze contemporary social movements working for environmental equity, and investigate policy and legal frameworks designed to address disproportionate environmental burdens. Through interdisciplinary readings, discussions, films, guest speakers, and field trips, students will develop a critical understanding of environmental justice principles and practices. Key themes include race, class, gender, indigeneity, climate justice, and food justice. Students will engage in research projects, policy analysis, and community-based learning opportunities to apply their knowledge to real-world environmental justice issues.
